can be used to evaluate the

human benefits while limited new infrastructure in areas of intact or critical habitats. For example, the
ap strategy has been used in parts of Southeast Asia

The extent and scale of mining is growing due to increased global demand
Due to declining ore grades, more ore needs to be
processed to meet demand, with extensive use of
carbon future may be more mineral intensive with for example, clean energy
technologies requiring greater inputs in comparison to fossil
impacts, especially in intensively mined regions
. The impact of mining on deforestation varies considerably across minerals and
countries. Mining causes significant changes to the environment, for example
infrastructure establishment, soil erosion, urban expansion to support a growing workforce and
development of mineral commodity supply chains
gold in developing countries, increased prices, and uncertainty in financial markets is identified as
driving gold mining and associated deforestati
Aide 2015; Dezécache et al. 2017; Asner and Tupayachi 2017; Espejo et al. 2018)
gold mining throughout the region increased by about 40% between 2012 and 2016
. In the Brazilian Amazon, mining significantly increased forest loss up to 70 km
beyond mining lease boundaries, causing 11,670 km
esenting 9% of all Amazon forest loss during this time
Mining is also an important driver of deforestation in African and Asian countries. In the Democratic
Republic of Congo, where the second
largest area of tropical forest in the world occurs, mining
. In India, mining has contributed to
deforestation at a district level, with coal, iron and limestone having had the most adverse impact on
. Gold mining is also identified as a dr
Wildland fires account for approximately 70% of the global biomass burned annually
and constitute a large global source of atmospheric trace gases and aerosols
ugh fires are part of the natural system, t
increased in many areas, exacerbated by decreases in precipitation, including in many regions with
humid and temperate forests that rarely experience large
, from peatlands through shrublands to tropical and boreal forests
